conclusion: The problem involves analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves backward above the objects.
General principle: Moving the light source higher or farther back increases the distance between the light and each object.
General principle: As the distance grows, rays reaching the ground arrive at a shallower angle.
Shallower-angle rays push the shadow away from the object, causing the shadow to slide in the same direction as the light moves.
Shallower-angle rays make the shadow footprint on the ground smaller, causing the penumbra to shrink and the umbra to contract.
Shadow A is currently positioned immediately beneath the cup with a slight offset toward the viewer.
When the light moves backward, shadow A shifts farther toward the viewer (toward the bottom of the picture) and contracts slightly in size.
Shadow B is currently a tight circular shadow just below the avocado with a small offset toward the viewer.
When the light moves backward, shadow B slides farther downward (same direction as shadow A) and becomes a smaller disk.
Shadow C is currently a long, elongated shadow pointing toward the lower left, already some distance from the tip of the cone.

When the light moves backward, the base of shadow C travels farther toward the viewer/lower edge, and the footprint narrows and shortens slightly, contracting overall in size while retaining its tapering shape.
Shadow D is currently a roughly square shadow just below the waffle block.
When the light moves backward, shadow D slides downward, appearing farther from the waffle block, and its dimensions shrink incrementally into a smaller square.
Summary: When the light source moves backward, all four shadows move away from their parent objects toward the bottom of the frame (toward the camera/viewer).

Summary: When the light source moves backward, all four shadows get noticeably smaller due to the expanding distance between the light and objects causing the shadow-cone cross-section at the floor to contract.
